walk out.translation[0].definitions[0].d: to leave a place suddenly, especially because you disapprove of something
walk out.translation[0].definitions[0].e: The play was awful and we walked out after half an hour.
the issue that led to the US walking out of the trade talks this week
walk out.translation[0].definitions[1].d: to leave your husband, wife etc suddenly and go and live somewhere else
walk out.translation[0].definitions[1].e: Her husband walked out, leaving her with three children to look after.
Five years later she walked out on Matthew and their two boys.
walk out.translation[0].definitions[2].d: to leave your job suddenly because you no longer want to do it
walk out.translation[0].definitions[2].e: We’re so short-staffed. I can’t just walk out.
If you can afford to walk out of your job, why not?
walk out.translation[0].definitions[3].d: to stop working as a protest
walk out.translation[0].definitions[3].e: Workers are threatening to walk out if an agreement is not reached.
